content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are fairly open to taking risks but still prefer to assess the situation carefully. You are not reckless, but you are not overly cautious either. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player who is open to taking risks but also prefers careful assessment of the situation, I would approach this game strategically by considering my opponent's potential moves and the long-term payoff.

In this game, picking R yields a higher average payoff when the opponent picks B, while picking B results in a higher average payoff when the opponent also picks B. However, the difference in payoffs is not significant when both players choose the same option.

Since the game has 75 rounds and the payoff for choosing the same option (B) in each round adds up to 12$, while the payoff for picking R (42$) will only be earned 3 times (when the opponent picks B), it seems more beneficial to play safe by choosing B most of the time.

Choosing B maximizes the average payoff over the long run, especially since we cannot predict with certainty what our anonymous opponent will choose. Therefore, my choice would be {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario where I picked R in the previous round but my opponent switched their strategy and chose B, I would stick with my original choice of R for the next round as well.

Even though my opponent chose B, it does not necessarily mean that they will continue to do so in future rounds. Since we cannot predict our opponent's future moves and the game has a large number of rounds (75), it is important to consider both the short-term and long-term payoffs when making decisions.

In this case, if my opponent decides to switch back to their original strategy of choosing R in the next round, I will earn 42$ by sticking with my choice of R. On the other hand, if my opponent continues to choose B, I will earn 0$. However, there is still a chance that my opponent might switch back to choosing R, and it would be beneficial for me to capitalize on that opportunity.

Therefore, I will continue to choose R for the next round as well. {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

In this situation where both of us chose B in the previous round and continue to do so, I would evaluate the potential outcomes for future rounds.

If we both continue to choose B consistently, we will earn a steady payoff of 12$ every time we play. However, there is also a chance that our opponent might switch their strategy and start choosing R, in which case my earnings could be significantly higher (up to 45$ per round).

On the other hand, if I decide to change my strategy and choose R instead, there is still a chance that my opponent might follow suit and earn a higher payoff of 42$, while I would only earn 12$.

Therefore, it is important to consider both the short-term (steady earnings) and long-term (potential for higher earnings by changing strategy) benefits when making decisions in this game.

In this case, I will continue to choose B for the next round as well. {B}

If we both continue to choose B consistently, we will earn a steady payoff of 12$ every time we play. However, there is also a chance that our opponent might switch their strategy and start choosing R, in which case my earnings could be significantly higher (up to 45$ per round). On the other hand, if I decide to change my strategy and choose R instead, there is still a chance that my opponent might follow suit and earn a higher payoff of 42$, while I would only earn 12$.

Therefore, it is important to consider both the short-term (steady earnings) and long-term benefits when making decisions in this game. In this case, since we are already earning steady income by choosing B consistently, I will continue to choose B for the next round as well. However, if the opportunity presents itself in future rounds, I may consider switching my strategy to R to capitalize on higher potential earnings.
